Problem:
Consider a system governed by the integral transformation \\( y(t) = \\int_{0}^{t} K(t, s) x(s) ds \\), where \\( K(t, s) \\) is a kernel function and \\( x(s) \\) is an input function. We study how manipulations through a specific function \\( g(x) = x + c \\), where \\( c \\) is a constant, influence the output \\( y(t) \\).

If \\( g(x) \\) is applied to an input function \\( x_0(s) \\) initially, and then \\( y(t) \\) evolves according to the integral transformation, will the outcome at time \\( t = T \\) be equivalent to directly evolving \\( x_0(s) \\) under the integral transformation without applying \\( g(x) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(x) \\) to \\( x_0(s) \\) alters the initial input to \\( x_0(s) + c \\), hence modifying the integral to \\( \\int_{0}^{T} K(T, s) (x_0(s) + c) ds \\) which results in an additional constant term \( c \\int_0^T K(T, s) ds \) compared to the original outcome. This constant adds a shift to all values, affecting the output value at time T.
